study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a 3-month aquatic exercise program (PICO) on knee osteoarthritis symptoms, physical function, quality of life, gait, inflammatory biomarkers, psychological health, lifestyle, and body composition.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results but outlines the study's intent to evaluate the PICO program's impact on KOA symptoms and quality of life, suggesting potential benefits for therapeutic interventions.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults (BMI 28-43.5 kg/m², age 40-65 years) with radiographic knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: To determine whether a dementia-specific aquatic exercise intervention reduces behavioral and psychological symptoms (BPSD) and improves psychological well-being in people with dementia.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant declines in behavioral and psychological symptoms (measured by RMBPC) and improvements in psychological well-being (measured by PW-BCIP) over the 12-week intervention period. The results suggest aquatic exercise may be beneficial for individuals with moderate to severe dementia.
population_specificity: Elderly residents (median age 88.4 years) with moderate to severe dementia from two aged care facilities in Queensland, Australia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (aquatic exercises for strength, agility, flexibility, balance, and relaxation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of aquatic exercise interventions with land-based exercises (home-based exercise) in improving pain, mobility, disease activity, disability, and quality of life in patients with ankylosing spondylitis.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise showed significant improvements in pain scores (VAS) and multiple quality-of-life subscales (SF-36) compared to home-based exercise at weeks 4 and 12. Both groups improved across all measured parameters, but aquatic exercise demonstrated superior outcomes in pain relief and mental health-related quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with ankylosing spondylitis (AS) (n=69).
effective_dosage: 20 sessions, 5× per week for 4 weeks in a swimming pool at 32-33 °C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate energy expenditure (EE) and cardiorespiratory (CR) responses during a 40-minute shallow-water aquatic exercise (AE) session in young adult women.
results_summary: The study found that a 40-minute AE session resulted in a total energy expenditure of 264 kcals, meeting national recommendations for moderate-to-vigorous physical activity. The CR segment contributed 65% of the total EE, with peak VO2 and heart rate responses indicating vigorous intensity.
population_specificity: Twenty-one healthy young adult women (aged 21.7 ± 3.4 years).
effective_dosage: 40-minute session (warm-up: 3 min, CR segment: 22 min, muscular endurance: 10 min, cool-down: 5 min).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the 24-week effects of a high-intensity aquatic exercise program on bone remodeling markers and bone mass in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The aquatic exercise program increased bone formation (P1NP) and attenuated bone resorption (CTx) compared to the control group, preventing femoral trochanter BMD reduction in the exercise group.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (58.8 ± 6.4 years)
effective_dosage: 500 mg elementary calcium and 1,000 IU vitamin D (cholecalciferol) daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of aquatic exercise versus dry land training on blood pressure in hypertensive post-menopausal women.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise significantly reduced systolic blood pressure from 136 ± 16 mm Hg to 124 ± 15 mm Hg over 12 weeks, comparable to dry land training. The control group showed no changes.
population_specificity: Post-menopausal hypertensive women (n=52).
effective_dosage: Not specified (training protocol performed over 12 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a 24-week aquatic exercise protocol in geothermal spring water for improving physical function and muscle mass in healthy elderly subjects, comparing it to land-based exercise and a control group.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise maintained knee-extension strength, improved dynamic balance more than land-based exercise, enhanced upper-body flexibility, reduced fat mass, and increased calf muscle density. Both exercise types improved lower-body flexibility.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly subjects (59 participants, aged not specified).

study_goal: To compare the bone mineral density (BMD) of postmenopausal women undergoing resistance training versus aquatic weight-bearing exercises.
results_summary: Both resistance training and aquatic weight-bearing exercises resulted in higher BMD at multiple sites compared to non-trained controls, with no significant differences between the two exercise groups.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women on hormone replacement therapy for at least one year.
effective_dosage: Not specified (training frequency/duration implied but not detailed).
study_duration: At least one year of training prior to the study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and effectiveness of deep water running (DWR) as part of a multimodal physiotherapy programme for reducing cancer-related fatigue and improving general health and quality of life in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in fatigue, general health, and quality of life for the experimental group, with high adherence and no major adverse events reported. The effect sizes ranged from moderate to large across different domains.
population_specificity: Primary breast cancer survivors recruited from community-based Primary Care Centres.
effective_dosage: 3 times a week for an 8-week period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of an aquatic exercise program (HydrOS) on neuromuscular function and falls among postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The aquatic exercise program significantly reduced falls and improved neuromuscular function, including flexibility, balance, mobility, and muscle strength, in postmenopausal women. The control group showed minor improvements, likely due to vitamin D supplementation.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (mean age 58.8 years).
effective_dosage: Aquatic exercise program (HydrOS) for 24 weeks; calcium 500 mg/day and cholecalciferol 1,000 IU/day for both groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a progressive aquatic resistance exercise program on cartilage composition, physical function, pain, bone traits, and quality of life in postmenopausal women with mild knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study will assess the impact of aquatic exercise on knee cartilage using advanced imaging techniques, alongside secondary outcomes like pain, function, and quality of life, but results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with mild knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on the effectiveness of aquatic exercises and balneotherapy in treating musculoskeletal conditions.
results_summary: Aquatic exercises showed small to moderate benefits in reducing pain and disability for musculoskeletal conditions, with effect sizes between 0.19 and 0.32. Balneotherapy may be beneficial, but evidence is insufficient for definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Patients with musculoskeletal conditions, including low back pain, osteoarthritis, fibromyalgia, and rheumatoid arthritis.

study_goal: To investigate the effectiveness of an 8-week aquatic exercise program on cancer-related fatigue, physical strength, and psychological outcomes in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The aquatic exercise group showed large improvements in fatigue, trunk endurance, and leg strength immediately post-intervention, with sustained effects at 6-month follow-up, but negligible effects on mood states.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors (N=68).
effective_dosage: 60-minute sessions (10 min warm-up, 40 min aerobic/endurance, 10 min cool-down), 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of low-intensity aquatic and floor exercises on patients with moderate to very severe COPD.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise improved physical ability (6MWT) and respiratory function (VEF1, MIP, MEP), while floor exercise enhanced quality of life (SGRQ) and reduced disease severity (BODE index). Both interventions showed benefits for COPD patients.
population_specificity: 42 individuals with moderate to very severe COPD.

study_goal: To investigate the impact of aquatic exercise on pressure pain threshold in breast cancer survivors with hormone therapy-associated arthralgia.
results_summary: Participants experienced a significant decrease in pressure pain threshold at neck, shoulder, hand, and leg, as well as reduced waist circumference. Cancer-related fatigue and body mass index did not show significant improvement.
population_specificity: Forty women aged 29-71 years with stage I-III breast cancer who reported arthralgia.
effective_dosage: 24 sessions over two months, 3 days per week, each session consisting of 5 minutes warm-up, 15-20 minutes aerobic exercise, 15 minutes mobility exercise, and 20 minutes recovery techniques.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the frequency and type of exercise recommendations, including aquatic exercise, for patients newly diagnosed with fibromyalgia.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise was the most frequently recommended type of exercise (56%) for fibromyalgia patients, followed by combined aquatic-aerobic exercise (26%). However, less than half of the patients received any exercise recommendations as part of their treatment plan.
population_specificity: Patients newly diagnosed with fibromyalgia (N = 122; mean age 45 ± 12 years; 91% women).

study_goal: To examine the effectiveness of aquatic exercise training on fatigue and health-related quality of life (HRQOL) in women with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Patients in the aquatic exercise group showed significant improvements in fatigue and HRQOL subscores after 4 and 8 weeks compared to the control group, with consistent results in both per-protocol and intention-to-treat analyses.
population_specificity: Women (N=32) diagnosed with relapsing-remitting MS (mean age ± SD, 32.6±8.0y).
effective_dosage: 3 times a week, each session lasting 60 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to compare the short-term effectiveness of high-intensity laser therapy (HILT) versus ultrasound (US) therapy in treating low back pain (LBP), not specifically evaluating Aquatic Exercise.
results_summary: The study found that HILT resulted in significantly greater pain reduction and disability improvement compared to US therapy in LBP patients, but Aquatic Exercise was not a focus of the study.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 14-week aquatic exercise program for improving swimming skills, cardiorespiratory endurance, muscular endurance, and mobility skills in children with autism spectrum disorders (ASD).
results_summary: The study found no significant between-group changes but noted within-group improvements in swimming skills for the intervention group. Parents and children reported high satisfaction with the program, though exercise intensity was low for some participants, likely contributing to the lack of significant fitness improvements.
population_specificity: Children with autism spectrum disorders (ASD)
effective_dosage: Twice per week for 40 minutes per session

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of aquatic exercise versus land-based exercise in reducing pain and improving functional outcomes in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Both aquatic and land-based exercise programs significantly improved pain, knee range of motion, six-minute walk test performance, and knee-related quality of life, but aquatic exercise was not superior to land-based exercise in pain reduction.
population_specificity: 84 participants with knee osteoarthritis recruited from local community centers.
effective_dosage: 60 minutes per session, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of structured aquatic and non-aquatic exercise programs on the static and dynamic balance of elderly people.
results_summary: The lower-limb muscle endurance program significantly improved balance in elderly participants, with no significant difference between aquatic and non-aquatic environments.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling elderly people (36 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of aquatic exercise (AQE) and land-based exercise (LBE) in improving knee function, reducing body fat, and enhancing quality of life in obese patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The AQE group showed significant reductions in body fat and pain interference, along with improvements in disability and quality of life, outperforming the LBE group in pain reduction. Both exercise groups improved disability scores compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Obese patients with knee osteoarthritis (BMI >25 kg/m², abdominal circumference >90 cm for men or >85 cm for women, Kellgren-Lawrence scale ≥2).
effective_dosage: Exercise interventions conducted 3 times a week.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of a community-based aquatic exercise program for improving quality of life in individuals with osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise significantly improved perceived quality of life (PQOL) scores, particularly among obese participants (BMI ≥ 30), but not in normal or overweight individuals. No tested variables mediated the relationship between aquatic exercise and PQOL.
population_specificity: Adults with osteoarthritis (n = 249).
effective_dosage: At least two aquatic exercise sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize findings on aquatic exercise and balneotherapy and assess the quality of systematic reviews based on randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Aquatic exercise had small but statistically significant short-term effects on pain relief and related outcome measures for locomotor diseases (e.g., arthritis, rheumatoid diseases, low back pain), but long-term effectiveness was unclear. Balneotherapy's effects remained inconclusive due to poor methodological quality in studies.
population_specificity: Individuals with locomotor diseases (e.g., arthritis, rheumatoid diseases, low back pain).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to survey recent research and patents on ALOX inhibitors, including arachidonic acid derivatives, for treating neurodegenerative diseases.
results_summary: The study found that several ALOX inhibitors show promising results for neurological disorders, but clinical evaluation is needed to assess therapeutic utility. Compounds with well-defined mechanisms and bioavailability may serve as lead treatments.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on research and patents).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of aquatic versus land-based exercises for early-phase recovery from acute lower extremity ligament injuries in elite athletes.
results_summary: Both groups showed improvements in pain, stability, and function, but the aquatic exercise group demonstrated steeper improvement curves, suggesting faster recovery compared to land-based therapy. No significant differences were found between groups in final outcomes, but aquatic exercise showed a more rapid progression.
population_specificity: Elite athletes with isolated grade I or II ligament injuries in ankles or knees.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercises included ranging, strengthening, proprioceptive training, and functional exercises).
study_duration: 4 weeks (measurements at baseline, 2 weeks, and 4 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how methanol extract of Scutellaria baicalensis Georgi (MESB) affects hepatic fibrosis, particularly its role in disrupting arachidonic acid metabolism.
results_summary: MESB suppressed arachidonic acid metabolism by downregulating cPLA2, leading to reduced production of arachidonic acid and its inflammatory mediators, thereby alleviating hepatic fibrosis.
population_specificity: CCl4-induced hepatic fibrosis mouse model and LX-2 cells (human hepatic stellate cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether inhibiting arachidonic acid (AA) metabolism could enhance immunotherapy efficacy in ARID1A-deficient colorectal cancer.
results_summary: The study found that AA pathway inhibitors, like aspirin, selectively inhibited ARID1A-deficient tumor growth and synergized with immune checkpoint inhibitors by enhancing CD8+ T cell activity and inhibiting vasculogenic mimicry. Low PTGS1 and PTGS2 expression in ARID1A-deficient cells created a reliance on the AA pathway, making it a targetable vulnerability.
population_specificity: ARID1A-deficient colorectal cancer patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether melatonin's protective role against heat stress-induced spermatogenic damage in dairy goats is mediated by regulating gut microbiota and inhibiting excessive synthesis of arachidonic acid (AA) in testicular tissue.
results_summary: The study found that AA-related metabolites were elevated in testicular tissue of heat-stressed dairy goats and mice, correlating with inflammation, oxidative stress, and spermatogenic disorders. Supplementation with AA exacerbated these adverse effects, while melatonin mitigated them by modulating gut microbiota and reducing AA synthesis.
population_specificity: Male dairy goats and mice subjected to heat stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining arachidonic acid (AA) with t,t-farnesol enhances its antibacterial and anti-biofilm effects against cariogenic bacteria S. mutans and S. sobrinus.
results_summary: The study found that t,t-farnesol lowered the minimum inhibitory and biofilm inhibitory concentrations of AA, enhancing its antibacterial and anti-biofilm effects. AA reduced metabolic activity in mature biofilms, while combined treatment increased membrane perforation and reduced biofilm-related gene expression.
population_specificity: Gram-positive bacteria (Streptococcus mutans and Streptococcus sobrinus) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of abnormal arachidonic acid metabolism in bladder dysfunction following traumatic spinal cord injury (TSCI).
results_summary: The study found that inflammatory changes and abnormal arachidonic acid metabolism correlated with bladder dysfunction post-TSCI, with significant detrusor contractility changes occurring by the third day.
population_specificity: Adult male Sprague-Dawley rats subjected to TSCI.
study_duration: Observations made up to seven days post-TSCI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Qingfei Zhisou oral liquid (QFZS) affects arachidonic acid metabolism and its role in regulating fever and inflammation.
results_summary: QFZS restored normal arachidonic acid levels and reduced inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β) and fever-related factors (PGE-2, cAMP). The anti-inflammatory effects were linked to transient receptor potential ion channel regulation.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats (n=60)
effective_dosage: Low and high doses of QFZS (specific amounts not stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of ARA + DHA supplementation on intestinal fatty acid composition, structure, and immune indicators supportive of oral tolerance development in allergy-prone rats.
results_summary: Weaning ARA + DHA increased DHA in ileum phospholipids and triglycerides, while suckling ARA + DHA elevated mucosal IL-2, sIgA, and TGF-β levels, suggesting a tolerogenic intestinal environment. OVA treatment reduced mucosal IL-6, and dietary ARA + DHA enhanced TGF-β post-OVA.
population_specificity: Allergy-prone Brown Norway rat offspring.
effective_dosage: Suckling (0.45% ARA, 0.8% DHA); weaning (0.5% ARA, 0.5% DHA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of arachidonic acid metabolism in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) progression and its association with the anti-rheumatic effects of Sporidiobolus pararoseus polysaccharides (SPP).
results_summary: The study found that SPP intervention significantly downregulated metabolites in the arachidonic acid metabolism pathway, which was highly correlated with anti-rheumatic activity. Arachidonic acid metabolism was identified as a critical driver of RA phenotypes and osteoclast differentiation, potentially linked to SPP-reshaped intestinal microbiota.
population_specificity: Collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of aquatic versus land-based exercise on function, mobility, and participant perception for adults with arthritis.
results_summary: No significant differences in outcomes were found between aquatic and land-based exercise in meta-analyses. Aquatic exercise was deemed a viable alternative for those who struggle with land-based exercise.
population_specificity: Adults with arthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of arachidonic acid (AA) metabolites in Angiotensin II-induced cardiac hypertrophy and how Cannabistilbene I modulates these pathways.
results_summary: The study found that Ang II elevated midchain (R/S)-HETE concentrations, which were reduced by Cannabistilbene I. Cannabistilbene I selectively increased 19(S)-HETE and reversed the Ang II-induced decline in 19(S)-HETE, suggesting a protective role in cardiac hypertrophy.
population_specificity: Adult human ventricular cardiomyocyte cell line (AC16)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acupuncture at ST36 modulates arachidonic acid metabolic pathways to improve inflammatory responses in Adjuvant-Induced Arthritis (AIA) mice.
results_summary: Acupuncture at ST36 corrected metabolic disorders in AIA mice, with 10 differential metabolites identified, primarily linked to arachidonic acid and pentose phosphate pathways, leading to significant inflammatory improvement.
population_specificity: Adjuvant-Induced Arthritis (AIA) model mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how inhibiting the arachidonic acid (AA) metabolic pathway could improve meningeal lymphatic drainage and reduce cognitive deficits in APP/PS1 mice with impaired lymphatic drainage.
results_summary: The study found that increased AA metabolic pathway activity contributed to neuropathological exacerbation in APP/PS1 mice with impaired lymphatic drainage. JWXG Decoction restored lymphatic drainage and improved cognitive performance by suppressing the AA metabolic pathway and reducing neuroinflammation.
population_specificity: APP/PS1 mice with impaired meningeal lymphatic drainage (a model for Alzheimer's disease).
effective_dosage: Clinically equivalent dose of JWXG Decoction (specific amount not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of repurposing compounds targeting the arachidonic acid cascade, particularly antiplatelet agents for cancer prevention and 5-lipoxygenase inhibitors for leukemia therapy.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the broader concept of drug repurposing and highlights the potential of targeting the arachidonic acid cascade for new therapeutic applications, but it does not provide specific results on Arachidonic Acid's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether arachidonic acid supplementation could mitigate cholestatic liver disease by improving bile acid uptake and reducing cholestasis markers.
results_summary: Arachidonic acid supplementation reduced serum markers of cholestasis, decreased bile duct hyperplasia, and upregulated Oatp1 expression, promoting bile acid uptake in hepatocytes. The findings suggest arachidonic acid may be an effective dietary intervention for cholestatic liver disease.
population_specificity: Mouse models of cholestatic liver disease (DDC diet and ANIT gavage models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether new intravenous lipid emulsions containing sufficient ARA and DHA could support normal development in preterm infants without causing liver toxicity.
results_summary: The new lipid emulsions maintained similar ARA levels in frontal cortex tissue compared to controls and prevented hepatosteatosis and biochemical liver injury, unlike commercially available emulsions.
population_specificity: Juvenile C57Bl/6J mice (as a model for preterm infants).
effective_dosage: Administered via daily orogastric gavage or every other day intravenously (specific amounts not detailed).
study_duration: Long-term experiment duration not specified; parenteral nutrition model lasted 19 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how varying concentrations of arachidonic acid (AA) regulate pluripotency, fatty acid synthesis, and mitochondrial activities in human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs) and human embryonal carcinoma (hEC) NTERA-2 cells.
results_summary: Lower concentrations of AA increased pluripotency, fatty acid synthesis, and mitochondrial fission, while higher concentrations induced differentiation of pluripotent stem cells. Molecular docking simulations suggested AA interacts with fatty acid synthesis regulators ACC1 and CREB1.
population_specificity: Human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs) and human embryonal carcinoma (hEC) NTERA-2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the production of Arachidonic Acid (ARA) using the fungus Mortierella alpina and assess its potential for commercial-scale production.
results_summary: The study found that shake flask cultivation of M. alpina at 25 °C for 7 days yielded 0.570 g ARA per liter, while mutagen treatment and temperature adjustments increased production to over 3 g ARA per liter, suitable for commercial use.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using fungal culture).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (production yield measured in g/liter).
study_duration: 7 days for initial cultivation; additional steps involved temperature adjustments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how the FOXA2-RND1 pathway, which modulates arachidonic acid (AA) metabolism, affects cisplatin (DDP) resistance in lung squamous cell carcinoma (LUSC) cells.
results_summary: The study found that RND1, which modulates the AA metabolism pathway, was downregulated in LUSC. Overexpression of RND1 reduced cell proliferation and DDP resistance while promoting apoptosis, suggesting that regulating AA levels via the FOXA2-RND1 pathway could enhance DDP sensitivity in LUSC cells.
population_specificity: Lung squamous cell carcinoma (LUSC) cells and DDP-resistant cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the remedial effects and mechanisms of Huangqi Guizhi Wuwu Decoction (HGWWD) on chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN), focusing on its regulation of arachidonic acid metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that HGWWD reversed the levels of 19 biomarkers related to CIPN, with prostaglandin H2 and 17α,21-dihydroxypregnenolone identified as core biomarkers. It primarily inhibited the inflammatory response during CIPN by regulating arachidonic acid metabolism.
population_specificity: Patients with chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of arachidonic acid (AA) metabolism in liver inflammation and lipid disturbances caused by YAP1 deficiency and assess DHA's potential to modulate these effects.
results_summary: Hepatocyte-specific Yap1 knockout activated the AA metabolic pathway, increasing AA, PGE1, and LT levels, leading to inflammation. DHA mitigated these effects by downregulating COX-2 and 5-LOX, reducing lipid vacuoles, and lowering TG and PLIN2 levels.
population_specificity: Yap1 Flox/Flox and Yap1 LKO mice (hepatocyte-specific Yap1 knockout).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of cannabigerol (CBG) on inflammation in colon tissue, including changes in arachidonic acid (AA) content and its derivatives under high-fat, high-sucrose diet conditions.
results_summary: CBG treatment reduced AA concentration in phospholipid (PL) and triacylglycerol (TAG) fractions, decreased the expression of inflammatory proteins (cPLA2, COX-1, COX-2, 12/15-LOX), and altered AA-derived mediators (lower LTB4, higher LXA4).
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats on a high-fat, high-sucrose diet.
effective_dosage: 30 mg/kg of body mass, administered intragastrically.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect and mechanism of quercetin on PRRSV-induced inflammation, including its impact on arachidonic acid metabolism.
results_summary: Quercetin suppressed PRRSV-induced arachidonic acid metabolism pathways, inhibited inflammatory markers, and attenuated viral replication in MARC-145 cells.
population_specificity: MARC-145 cells (a monkey kidney cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of abnormal arachidonic acid metabolism in gastrointestinal cancers and its potential as a therapeutic target.
results_summary: The study found that abnormal arachidonic acid metabolism and altered metabolite levels may play a significant role in the development of gastrointestinal cancers, with potential implications for future therapies.
population_specificity: Patients with gastrointestinal cancers (liver, colorectal, pancreatic, esophageal, gastric, and gallbladder cancers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how guava polysaccharides (GP) influence arachidonic acid (AA) metabolism and its role in hypoglycemic effects via gut microbiota modulation.
results_summary: GP elevated hepatic AA and 15-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid while reducing prostaglandin E2 and other hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acids, suggesting AA metabolism modulation contributes to GP's hypoglycemic effects. These changes were linked to gut microbiota alterations.
population_specificity: High-fat diet- and streptozotocin-induced hyperglycemic model (likely animal study, not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how arachidonic acid (AA) interacts with common antibacterial compounds (chlorhexidine, cetylpyridinium chloride, triclosan, and fluoride) in reducing Streptococcus mutans growth and biofilm formation.
results_summary: AA demonstrated anti-bacterial and anti-biofilm activity against Streptococcus mutans. Combined treatment with triclosan and fluoride enhanced AA's efficacy, while chlorhexidine and cetylpyridinium chloride showed antagonistic effects at certain concentrations.
population_specificity: Streptococcus mutans (bacterial culture model)
interactions: Antagonistic effects with chlorhexidine and cetylpyridinium chloride; additive effects with triclosan and fluoride.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of arachidonic acid (AA) metabolism in obesity susceptibility by comparing obesity-prone and obesity-resistant mice models.
results_summary: The study found that AA metabolism was significantly reduced in obesity-resistant mice and was the most enriched pathway in KEGG analysis, suggesting a strong link between AA metabolites, gut microbiota, and obesity resistance.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice fed high-fat diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of arachidonic acid (AA) in ferroptosis and its regulation by Si-Wu-Tang (SWT) in a mouse model of MAFLD.
results_summary: The study found that AA esterification, mediated by ACSL4, contributed to hepatocyte ferroptosis in MAFLD, and SWT effectively inhibited this process. SWT's active ingredients, including paeoniflorin, were identified as potential regulators of AA-related ferroptosis and lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: Methionine-choline-deficient (MCD) diet-fed mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Arachidonic Acid (AA) metabolism in the therapeutic effects of Aucubin (AU) on glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis (GIOP) and its regulatory mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that AA metabolism is a common pathway affected in GIOP and AU treatment, with AU upregulating PTGS2 and PTGES expression while downregulating PTGDS. AU's mechanism in treating GIOP involves regulating AA metabolism and promoting osteoblast differentiation.
population_specificity: Female mice with glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis.
effective_dosage: High-dose AU (AUH) was used, but specific amounts and frequency were not detailed in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cannflavin-C modulates arachidonic acid (AA) metabolites and attenuates angiotensin II-induced cardiac hypertrophy.
results_summary: The study found that cannflavin-C downregulated CYP1B1, reducing AA metabolite (midchain HETEs) concentrations and mitigating angiotensin II-induced cardiac hypertrophy markers.
population_specificity: Adult human ventricular cardiomyocyte (AC16) cell line

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the mechanisms underlying Arachidonic Acid's schistosomicidal potential against Schistosoma mansoni and Schistosoma hematobium in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: Arachidonic Acid disrupted the outer membrane organization, integrity, and sphingomyelin content of male and female worms, and additionally stimulated neutral sphingomyelinase activity and oxidative stress in female parasites, supporting its efficacy as a schistosomicidal agent.
population_specificity: Laboratory rodents, children in low and high endemicity regions, and ex vivo Schistosoma mansoni worms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of arachidonic acid in aging-related type 2 diabetes and its potential as a therapeutic target.
results_summary: The study found that arachidonic acid levels were elevated in elderly individuals and aged mice, correlating with hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance. Inhibiting arachidonic acid production with varespladib improved these metabolic dysfunctions in aged mice.
population_specificity: Chinese elderly adults and aged mice.
effective_dosage: Not specified for arachidonic acid; varespladib was administered daily for two weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how functional peptides in Saiga antelope horn (SAH) interact with the arachidonic acid pathway to treat febrile seizures.
results_summary: SAH peptides (e.g., YGQL, LTGGF) inhibited arachidonic acid (AA) and its metabolites by binding to PTGS2, reducing inflammation and regulating neurotransmitter balance in FS model rats.
population_specificity: Rat pups with induced febrile seizures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the correlation between arachidonic acid metabolites and ovarian cancer, exploring their potential as biomarkers for diagnosis, therapy, and prognosis.
results_summary: The study found that arachidonic acid and its metabolites play significant regulatory roles in ovarian cancer onset and progression, suggesting their utility in early diagnosis, targeted therapy, and prognosis monitoring.
population_specificity: Ovarian cancer patients (domestic and international studies reviewed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Coptisine on arachidonic acid metabolism and its role in neuroprotection during cerebral ischemia-reperfusion injury.
results_summary: The study found that Coptisine treatment upregulated cyclopentenone PGs and increased the ratios of DHETs to arachidonic acid, suggesting a regulatory role in arachidonic acid metabolism linked to anti-inflammatory effects and neuroprotection.
population_specificity: Cerebral ischemia-reperfusion injury model in rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of α-terpineol in asthma and its potential mechanism, particularly focusing on its impact on arachidonic acid (AA) metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that α-terpineol reduced AA levels, downregulated 5-LOX expression, and decreased CysLTs accumulation in lung tissues, demonstrating its protective effect against asthma by regulating disordered AA metabolism.
population_specificity: Asthmatic mice (murine model)
study_duration: One week (after OVA sensitization and challenge)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of arsenic trioxide (ATO) on the hepatic formation of arachidonic acid (AA) metabolites and their producing CYP enzymes, to understand ATO-induced hepatotoxicity.
results_summary: ATO altered hepatic AA metabolite formation by modulating CYP enzymes, increasing 17(S)-HETE, 18(R)-HETE, and 20-HETE while decreasing 18(S)-HETE, suggesting a link to ATO-induced hepatotoxicity.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the radioprotective mechanisms of Arachidonic Acid (ARA) in mitigating adverse effects of high-dose 131I therapy in differentiated thyroid cancer (DTC) patients and irradiation in mice.
results_summary: ARA supplementation improved quality of life, recovered hematopoietic and gastrointestinal systems, reduced oxidative stress and inflammation, and preserved gut microbiota composition in irradiated mice. Antibiotic intervention nullified ARA's radioprotective effects, highlighting its dependence on gut microecology.
population_specificity: DTC patients receiving high-dose 131I therapy and irradiated mice.
interactions: Antibiotic pretreatment eliminated ARA's radioprotective effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how PIK3CA mutant tumor cells use exosomal arachidonic acid (AA) to promote malignant transformation in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs) and explore AA as a potential therapeutic target for colorectal cancer (CRC) with PIK3CA mutations.
results_summary: The study found that PIK3CA mutations increase AA synthesis via SGK3-FBW7-mediated cPLA2 stability, and exosomal AA transfer to IECs enhances H3K4 trimethylation by strengthening Menin-MLL1/2 interactions. Combining VTP50469 (Menin-MLL inhibitor) and alpelisib synergistically suppressed PIK3CA-mutant tumors.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer (CRC) with PIK3CA mutations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify metabolites, including arachidonic acid, that may have a causal role in bipolar disorder (BPD) using a metabolome-wide Mendelian randomization approach.
results_summary: Arachidonic acid was significantly associated with BPD (β = -0.154, SE = 0.023, p = 3.30 × 10^-11), suggesting a potential causal role. The associations were driven by genetic variants in the FADS1/2/3 gene cluster, indicating a shared genetic etiology with BPD.
population_specificity: 14,296 Europeans, with BPD outcome data from 41,917 BPD cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of arachidonic acid and its metabolites in atherosclerosis development and progression.
results_summary: Elevated levels of arachidonic acid and its metabolite leukotriene B4 were observed in atherosclerosis patients and animal models, suggesting a crucial role in disease regulation. Inhibition of arachidonic acid and monitoring its downstream metabolites revealed its involvement in atherosclerosis metabolic pathways.
population_specificity: Atherosclerosis patients and animal models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how CFTR, activated by GATA6, modulates the arachidonic acid (AA) metabolism pathway to influence lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) progression.
results_summary: The study found that CFTR, enriched in the AA metabolism pathway, hampers LUAD progression when activated by GATA6. Inhibition of the AA pathway mitigated the stimulatory effects of low CFTR expression on LUAD progression.
population_specificity: Lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of evolocumab treatment and lipoprotein apheresis on the fatty acid profile, particularly arachidonic acid, and its derived lipid mediators in blood samples.
results_summary: Changing from lipoprotein apheresis to evolocumab treatment reduced levels of arachidonic acid and other omega-6 PUFAs, as well as their derived oxylipins, suggesting a potential beneficial effect on cardiovascular risk.
population_specificity: 37 patients with treatment-resistant familial hypercholesterolemia (19 on lipoprotein apheresis, 18 on evolocumab).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether arachidonic acid (AA) protects against diabetic myocardial ischemic injury by promoting mitochondrial autophagy and renewal, and to explore its mechanism via AA-derived PGI2 signaling.
results_summary: AA treatment reduced cell death in cardiomyocytes under high glucose and oxygen deprivation, improved mitochondrial function, and decreased infarct size, apoptosis, and inflammation in diabetic rats. Lower plasma AA levels in diabetic patients post-myocardial infarction correlated with poorer cardiac function.
population_specificity: Diabetic Bama-mini pigs, diabetic Sprague Dawley rats, and diabetic patients post-myocardial infarction.
study_duration: Not specified for in vitro studies; intervention duration in rats not explicitly stated.
interactions: Inhibited by indomethacin and Cay10441 (prostacyclin receptor antagonist).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects and systemic mechanism of Zishen Yutai pills (ZYP), particularly focusing on its role in arachidonic acid metabolism, for treating cisplatin-induced premature ovarian failure (POF).
results_summary: ZYP reversed follicle reduction, increased serum estradiol and ovarian AMH levels, and restored fertility in cisplatin-induced POF mice. Proteomic and metabolomic analyses identified arachidonic acid metabolism as a key pathway, with ZYP upregulating critical targets like CYP17α1, HSD3β1, LHR, STAR, and AKT.
population_specificity: Cisplatin-induced premature ovarian failure (POF) in mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how the Panax notoginseng-Salvia miltiorrhiza (PS) herb pair affects arachidonic acid (AA) metabolism and its role in blood stasis activation.
results_summary: The study found that PS (3:1 ratio) increased AA content and reduced PGF2-α by modulating enzyme expression, suggesting it blocks AA conversion to prostaglandins, improving blood stasis.
population_specificity: SD rats with induced traumatic blood stasis (TBS).
effective_dosage: PS herb pair at ratios of 1:0, 0:1, 3:1, 1:1, and 1:3 (specific dosage amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether activation of the arachidonic acid cascade contributes to cognitive impairment during MDMA withdrawal.
results_summary: The study found that arachidonic acid cascade activation in the hippocampus is linked to recognition memory impairment during MDMA withdrawal, and this effect was mitigated by co-administration of a cyclooxygenase inhibitor (diclofenac).
population_specificity: Mice
effective_dosage: MDMA (10mg/kg, i.p., once daily); diclofenac (10mg/kg, i.p.)
interactions: Cyclooxygenase inhibitors (e.g., diclofenac) may reduce MDMA-induced cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of arachidonic acid-derived lipid mediators in the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis and explore potential therapeutic interventions targeting these pathways.
results_summary: The study found that arachidonic acid-derived lipid mediators contribute to neuroinflammation, demyelination, and neurodegeneration in multiple sclerosis, suggesting their involvement in disease progression. The review proposes modulating the eicosanoid pathway as a novel therapeutic strategy to combat these pathological processes.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between serum EPA/AA ratio and the efficacy of immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) treatment in non-small cell lung cancer patients.
results_summary: Higher serum EPA/AA ratios were associated with improved overall survival in lung cancer patients treated with ICI, suggesting that arachidonic acid levels relative to EPA may influence treatment efficacy. The study also found that long-term survivors consumed more seafood, which correlated with higher EPA/AA ratios.
population_specificity: Patients with non-small cell lung cancer undergoing initial pembrolizumab (ICI) treatment.
study_duration: Dietary patterns were analyzed in the month before treatment; survival outcomes were tracked for ≥3 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of arachidonic acid (AA) on autoimmune diabetes and its potential cross-talk with DPP-4 inhibitors in NOD mice.
results_summary: AA treatment reduced blood glucose, preserved islet morphology, and alleviated inflammatory cell infiltration in pancreatic islets, accompanied by changes in serum cytokine levels. However, it did not affect diabetes incidence or weight.
population_specificity: Non-Obese Diabetic (NOD) mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high fatty acid conditions, particularly involving arachidonic acid (AA) metabolism, interfere with the effects of statins on hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) progression.
results_summary: The study found that arachidonic acid metabolism was significantly altered by atorvastatin in high fatty acid conditions, promoting HCC cell proliferation and migration. PTGES2, a key enzyme in AA metabolism, was associated with poor HCC outcomes and was upregulated by atorvastatin via SREBP2-mediated transcription.
population_specificity: Mice fed high fatty acid diets (HFD) and HCC cell lines.
interactions: Atorvastatin (a statin) and linoleic acid (LA), a precursor to AA.

study_goal: To determine if AUDA (an sEH inhibitor) mitigates postpartum depression-like symptoms in rats by regulating the AA/NF-κB pathway and suppressing inflammation in the prefrontal cortex.
results_summary: AUDA attenuated depression-like behavior in PPD rats, reversed inflammatory markers (5-LOX, COX-2, sEH, IL-1β, IL-6, p65, p-p65, P-IκBα, NF-κB p65, GFAP), and increased epoxyeicosatrienoic acids and 5-HT levels, similar to paroxetine hydrochloride.
population_specificity: Sprague Dawley rats with induced postpartum depression-like symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of arachidonic acid metabolism in FCS-induced metabolic disorders and inflammation via gut microbiota.
results_summary: The study found that FCS increased arachidonic acid metabolism and prostaglandin production, which correlated with metabolic disorders and inflammation in mice.
population_specificity: Mice fed with 30% FCS drinking water.
effective_dosage: 30% FCS in drinking water (specific dosage not quantified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of arachidonic acid (AA) metabolism in intervertebral disc degeneration (IVDD) and identify potential biomarkers and therapeutic targets.
results_summary: The study found a positive correlation between AA metabolic pathway activity and IVDD severity, identified five hub genes linked to inflammation and immune response, and demonstrated that AH6809 could delay IVDD by inhibiting AKR1C3.
population_specificity: Patients with intervertebral disc degeneration (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how PIK3CA mutations in luminal breast cancer cells utilize the arachidonic acid metabolism pathway to induce an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment and whether targeting this pathway could enhance immunotherapy efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that PIK3CA-mutant luminal breast cancer cells recruit myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) and exclude cytotoxic T cells via the arachidonic acid (AA) metabolism pathway, specifically through 5-LOX-dependent LTB4 production. Targeting the PI3K/5-LOX/LTB4 axis synergized with immune checkpoint blockade therapy, leading to significant tumor shrinkage in vivo.
population_specificity: Refractory advanced luminal breast cancer patients with PIK3CA mutations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between the DHA/arachidonic acid (ARA) ratio and autistic social behaviors, focusing on lipid peroxidation and neuronal deficiencies.
results_summary: The study found that an unbeneficial DHA/ARA ratio was associated with increased MDA-LDL levels and ferroptosis, contributing to autistic social behaviors. Plasma levels of MDA-LDL and the DHA/ARA ratio were significantly higher in the ASD group compared to controls.
population_specificity: 18 individuals with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) and 8 age-matched controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how L. plantarum Zhang-LL strains (live or heat-killed) influence CRC progression, particularly focusing on the arachidonic acid metabolism pathway.
results_summary: The study found that high doses of L. plantarum Zhang-LL (live or heat-killed) inhibited the arachidonic acid metabolism pathway, reduced PGE2 expression, and improved host immunogenicity, thereby alleviating CRC progression. These effects were linked to reduced inflammation and tumorigenesis.
population_specificity: Mouse model of colorectal cancer (CRC) induced by azomethane and dextran sodium sulfate.
effective_dosage: High- and low-doses of L. plantarum Zhang-LL (specific amounts not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the biological effects and potential role of ALOX15 in the pathogenesis of diabetes mellitus (DM) and explore ALOX15 inhibitors as a novel therapeutic direction.
results_summary: The study found that ALOX15 and its products are linked to immune and inflammatory diseases, including DM, and suggests that ALOX15 inhibitors may offer a new treatment approach for DM and its complications.
population_specificity: Human tissues and broadly related to diseases such as DM, liver, cardiovascular, and cerebrovascular diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Hibiscus sabdariffa L (HSL) at 2% improves renal function in metabolic syndrome by modulating arachidonic acid (AA) metabolites.
results_summary: HSL treatment improved renal function and structure in metabolic syndrome rats by reducing perfusion pressure, COX2 and CYP450 activity, and increasing AA percentage and PLA2 expression. It favored the COX1 pathway while inhibiting other AA metabolic pathways.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic mechanism of TFRD on osteoarthritis (OA), particularly its relationship with arachidonic acid metabolism and COX-2 inhibition.
results_summary: TFRD reduced chondrocyte apoptosis and cartilage degeneration in OA rats, with serum metabolomics linking its effects to arachidonic acid metabolism. TFRD inhibited COX-2 mRNA expression and modulated AMPK/NFκB pathways in both in vivo and in vitro models.
population_specificity: OA model rats and IL-1β-induced chondrocytes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how quercetin, a component of saffron, affects breast cancer progression by modulating arachidonic acid metabolism and its downstream effects on Stat3 signaling.
results_summary: Quercetin inhibited breast cancer progression by down-regulating CYP3A4, reducing the metabolization of arachidonic acid to EETs, and blocking Stat3 nuclear translocation, thereby impeding tumor growth in vitro and in vivo. Exogenous EETs counteracted quercetin's anti-tumor effects.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cells (in vitro) and tumor-bearing nude mice (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of arachidonic acid (AA) metabolism in health and disease, focusing on its biochemical roles, disease progression implications, and potential therapeutic interventions.
results_summary: The study found that AA is a precursor to bioactive lipid metabolites involved in cell differentiation, tissue development, and disease progression, including hepatic fibrosis, neurodegeneration, obesity, diabetes, and cancers. It also highlighted that interventions targeting AA metabolic pathways are effective in managing inflammatory-related diseases, with inhibitors being a key area of drug discovery.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of AA metabolism in mammalian cells and disease contexts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Zhisou Powder (ZP) affects arachidonic acid (AA) metabolism and its role in treating chronic bronchitis (CB).
results_summary: The study found that ZP reprogrammed disordered AA metabolism, contributing to its therapeutic effect on CB by inhibiting the PI3K/Akt/HIF-1α/VEGFA signaling pathway and exhibiting anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: SO2-induced CB model rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the specificity of sebocytes for linoleic acid (LA) and dissect the different roles of LA and arachidonic acid (AA) in regulating sebocyte functions.
results_summary: The study found that AA and LA had overlapping effects on genes involved in lipid metabolism and immune functions, but LA had more pronounced effects on lipid profiles and regulated additional pathways like cholesterol biosynthesis and differentiation. LA's effects were both AA-dependent and independent, suggesting potential therapeutic applications for sebaceous gland-related inflammatory skin diseases.
population_specificity: Sebocytes (skin cells involved in sebum production)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of cannabidiol (CBD) on arachidonic acid (AA) levels and its role in myocardial inflammation and oxidative balance under lipid overload conditions.
results_summary: CBD reduced AA content, particularly in the phospholipid pool, and modulated inflammatory markers by decreasing nuclear factor kappa B, cyclooxygenase-1, and -2 expression, leading to reduced prostaglandin E2 and increased prostaglandin I2.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats on a high-fat diet.
effective_dosage: Intraperitoneal CBD injections (specific dosage not mentioned) for the last 14 days.
study_duration: 7 weeks (CBD administered during the last 14 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether immobilization or exposure to ceftriaxone (CTA) affected the accumulation of arachidonic acid (ARA) in Lobosphaera sp. and how nitrogen deprivation influenced ARA production.
results_summary: The study found that neither immobilization nor CTA exposure affected ARA accumulation in Lobosphaera sp., but nitrogen deprivation increased ARA accumulation by 2.5 times in suspended cells and 1.7 times in chitosan-immobilized cells.
population_specificity: Lobosphaera sp. IPPAS C-2047 microalgae

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of varying dietary arachidonic acid (ARA) levels on growth performance, antioxidant capacity, tissue fatty acid profiles, and lipid metabolism in mud crab juveniles.
results_summary: Optimal ARA levels (5.20–6.20 g/kg) improved growth, antioxidant capacity, and lipid metabolism in mud crabs, while higher doses reduced lipogenesis and enhanced fatty acid oxidation. Tissue ARA content increased with dietary ARA levels, and specific gene expressions related to lipid metabolism were modulated.
population_specificity: Mud crab (Scylla paramamosain) juveniles (initial weight 11.29 ± 0.09 g).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the functional roles of mono-trans isomers of arachidonic acid (mtAA) and their effects on ferroptosis compared to natural cis-configured arachidonic acid (AA).
results_summary: The study found that natural cis-configured AA promoted ferroptosis, while mtAA exhibited an anti-ferroptotic effect. Membrane lipidome analysis revealed significant differences in fatty acid remodeling between the two cell fates, with mtPUFA formation and SFA enrichment occurring during ferroptosis.
population_specificity: HT1080 and MEF cell cultures

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of arachidonic acid (AA) metabolic pathway activation in conferring lobaplatin resistance in osteosarcoma cells.
results_summary: The study found that FUBP1 regulates PTGES transcription, activating the AA metabolic pathway, which leads to lobaplatin resistance in osteosarcoma cells. Targeting FUBP1, PTGES, or the AA pathway may sensitize resistant cells to lobaplatin.
population_specificity: Osteosarcoma cell lines and clinical specimens, compared with osteoblast cells and normal bone specimens.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize literature on the association between the arachidonic acid pathway and male fertility, focusing on prostaglandins and their potential role in improving fertility.
results_summary: The study found that PGE levels are significantly decreased in the semen of infertile men, suggesting that targeting the AA pathway could improve male fertility. Ibuprofen was noted to affect sperm function and semen parameters, indicating potential for PGE agonists in treatment.
population_specificity: Male fertility studies, including both animal models and human clinical trials.
interactions: Ibuprofen was mentioned to affect male fertility, but no other interactions were noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether arachidonic acid (AA) could synergize with CD8+ T cell-derived IFN-γ to induce ACSL4-mediated immunogenic tumor ferroptosis, enhancing cancer immunotherapy efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that AA, released from PLA2 catalysis, was converted into arachidonyl-CoA under ACSL4 activation stimulated by IFN-γ, leading to phospholipid peroxidation and immunogenic tumor ferroptosis. This process, combined with ROS generation and GSH/GPX4 depletion, significantly enhanced tumor immunogenicity and therapeutic outcomes.
population_specificity: Tumor cells in a preclinical setting (no human subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms behind arachidonic acid's tumoricidal effects for potential cancer prevention and management.
results_summary: Arachidonic acid impaired tumor cell proliferation, activated neutral sphingomyelinase, increased ceramide levels, and exposed beta 2 microglobulin on cell surfaces, but its effects were independent of ROS generation or caspase 3/7 activation.
population_specificity: Hepatocellular, lung, and breast carcinoma cell lines, along with normal hepatocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between the EPA/AA ratio and plaque characteristics in patients with acute coronary syndrome caused by plaque rupture.
results_summary: A higher EPA/AA ratio was associated with older age, lower peak creatine kinase, and a higher prevalence of layered and calcified plaques. The high EPA/AA ratio was an independent factor in determining the development of these plaque types.
population_specificity: 95 patients with acute coronary syndrome caused by plaque rupture who did not take lipid-lowering drugs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the associations between PUFA consumption (particularly arachidonic acid) and schizophrenia incidence rates, and to determine causal effects using Mendelian randomization.
results_summary: The study found that arachidonic acid (AA) and ω-6 LCPUFA consumption were inversely correlated with schizophrenia incidence rates, with AA and gamma-linolenic acid (GLA) identified as protective factors. No significant relationships were observed between schizophrenia and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) or other ω-3 PUFAs.
population_specificity: National schizophrenia incidence rates across 24 countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of arachidonic acid (ARA) biosynthesis and metabolism in glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) tumorigenesis, focusing on key enzymes and lipid mediators.
results_summary: The study found that ARA-derived lipid mediators promote GBM cancer cell proliferation, angiogenesis, immune system suppression, and treatment resistance. It detailed the involvement of specific enzymes (FADS1, FADS2, ELOVL5) and metabolic pathways (COX, LOX, cytochrome P450) in ARA processing.
population_specificity: Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) tumors and associated cancer processes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a ketogenic diet (KD) reduces oxidative stress by increasing Arachidonic Acid (ARA) and beta-hydroxybutyrate (BHB) as a potential mechanism for alleviating seizures in children with drug-resistant epilepsy (DRE).
results_summary: The study found that serum levels of ARA and BHB significantly increased after KD therapy, correlating with reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA and 8-OHdG) and a 61.76% responder rate (≥50% seizure reduction). BHB's role in reducing oxidative stress and seizures appeared more pronounced than ARA's.
population_specificity: Forty children with refractory epilepsy (34 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how hypoxia-induced changes in cytochrome P450 (CYP) expression and activity affect the metabolism of endogenous substances, including arachidonic acid, and their role in high-altitude diseases.
results_summary: The study found that hypoxia influences CYP expression and activity, which mediates changes in the metabolism of endogenous substances like arachidonic acid, potentially impacting high-altitude disease pathophysiology. However, the specific mechanisms and effects of these changes remain unclear.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on high-altitude hypoxia effects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the impact of inflammation on CYP-derived arachidonic acid metabolites and their role in cardiac hypertrophy and heart failure.
results_summary: The study found that CYP-mediated arachidonic acid metabolites, such as pro-inflammatory HETEs and anti-inflammatory EETs, play a role in cardiac hypertrophy. Inflammation modulates CYP enzyme expression and their metabolites, influencing disease progression.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the local and systemic metabolome-wide changes in tomatoes induced by Arachidonic Acid (AA) and Ascophyllum nodosum extract (ANE) to understand their roles in plant defense and resistance.
results_summary: The study found that AA and ANE root treatments significantly altered the tomato metabolome, enriching defense-related secondary metabolites such as fatty acyl-glycosides and hydroxycinnamic acids, and shared metabolic changes linked to ligno-suberin biosynthesis and phenolic compound synthesis.
population_specificity: Tomato plants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of arachidonic acid-derived mediators in endothelial dysfunction and the potential of polyphenol-rich foods to counteract these effects.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that arachidonic acid-derived mediators contribute to endothelial dysfunction by promoting vasocontracting factors and oxidative stress, while polyphenol-rich foods, particularly anthocyanin-rich products, may counteract these effects by enhancing vasoprotective factors.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies (endothelial cells, isolated blood vessels) and clinical data involving humans with cardiovascular diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether arachidonic acid (AA) supplementation affects human muscle cells similarly to its effects on murine cells, specifically focusing on myoblast proliferation and myotube hypertrophy.
results_summary: High concentrations of AA (50 µM and 25 µM) inhibited myoblast proliferation, reduced myotube fusion and hypertrophy, and suppressed anabolic signaling pathways in human muscle cells, indicating potential deleterious effects on skeletal muscle health. These effects were not mitigated by COX-2 inhibition with celecoxib.
population_specificity: Primary human myoblasts and myotubes (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 50 µM and 25 µM, administered for 48 hours (myoblasts) or 72 hours (myotubes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Arachidonic Acid (AA) in biological processes, particularly in immunity and cancer, focusing on its production by sPLA2 enzymes and its impact on tumor initiation and progression.
results_summary: The study found that AA and its derivatives, produced by sPLA2, significantly influence cellular environments, particularly in promoting EMT, angiogenesis, and immunomodulation, which are relevant in cancer contexts. The abstract also highlights ongoing research into sPLA2 inhibitors for cancer treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (general biological and cancer-related contexts)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of arachidonic acid metabolism in the prognosis of esophageal cancer (ESCA) by analyzing its association with anoikis-related gene signatures.
results_summary: The study found that low-risk ESCA patients were associated with arachidonic acid metabolism, suggesting a potential metabolic pathway involvement in prognosis. No direct effects or outcomes of arachidonic acid supplementation were evaluated.
population_specificity: Patients with esophageal cancer (ESCA) from the TCGA-ESCA database.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of omega-3 supplementation on modulating inflammation in obesity, potentially involving Arachidonic Acid pathways.
results_summary: The study concluded that a diet supplemented with EPA and DHA (omega-3 fatty acids) was effective in bypassing a synthesis step affected by obesity, suggesting potential benefits for inflammation modulation.
population_specificity: Seventy-six subjects with obesity.
effective_dosage: 1.5 g of omega-3 (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Arachidonic Acid and other endocannabinoid system metabolites are altered in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients and could serve as biomarkers.
results_summary: The study found that Arachidonic Acid was elevated in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of male MS patients, but no significant changes were observed in serum. Sex-specific differences were noted, with males showing increased levels of Arachidonic Acid and other endocannabinoids in CSF.
population_specificity: 74 MS patients and 80 non-neuroinflammatory control patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of arachidonic acid (AA) peroxidation products (isoprostanes) as biomarkers of oxidative stress and their potential implications in neurodegenerative and cardiovascular diseases.
results_summary: The study found that isoprostanes, derived from AA peroxidation, serve as reliable markers of oxidative stress and may have biological activities relevant to neurodegenerative and cardiovascular diseases. These metabolites provide insights into oxidative damage mechanisms and potential therapeutic applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on oxidative stress-related diseases).

study_goal: The researchers explored the role of arachidonic acid released by phospholipase A2 (PLA2) in Russell's viper venom and its pharmacological effects, as well as the limitations of current antivenom treatments.
results_summary: The study found that arachidonic acid, released by PLA2 in snake venom, contributes to various toxic effects such as hemolysis, anticoagulation, neurotoxicity, myotoxicity, and edema. The abstract highlights the need for next-generation antivenoms to target low-molecular-weight toxins like PLA2.
population_specificity: Not applicable (review of venom mechanisms and antivenom limitations, not a human trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of prostaglandins derived from arachidonic acid in neurological disorders, focusing on their potential neuroprotective or neurotoxic effects in Alzheimer's Disease, Multiple Sclerosis, and Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.
results_summary: The study highlights the dual role of prostaglandins in the CNS, with potential neuroprotective or neurotoxic effects depending on receptor interactions, and discusses the therapeutic potential of prostaglandin-related agonists and antagonists for neurological diseases.
population_specificity: Preclinical and clinical settings, focusing on neurological disorders (Alzheimer's Disease, Multiple Sclerosis, Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of oxylipins, particularly those derived from arachidonic acid, in ovarian function and disease, and to identify potential therapeutic interventions targeting the oxylipin pathway.
results_summary: The study found that oxylipins, including prostaglandins and leukotrienes from arachidonic acid, play a regulatory role in follicle growth, ovulation, and hormone regulation, and their dysregulation is linked to ovarian diseases such as endometriosis and polycystic ovary syndrome. Potential therapeutic interventions targeting the oxylipin pathway were highlighted.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on ovarian function and disease in females).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of arachidonic acid-derived leukotrienes in inflammation and neurodegeneration, focusing on their biosynthesis, receptors, and biological effects.
results_summary: The study found that leukotrienes, produced from arachidonic acid via 5-LOX, play a significant role in inflammatory signaling, particularly in CNS disorders like MS, AD, and PD, suggesting potential therapeutic targets for neurodegeneration.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on neurodegenerative diseases)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of arachidonic acid and other lipids in regulating synaptic function, ion channel activity, and their contribution to neurological and neuropsychiatric diseases.
results_summary: The study found that arachidonic acid, along with other membrane lipids, plays a critical role in regulating synaptic receptors, ion channels, and neural functions, and may contribute to brain plasticity and disease development.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of brain lipids)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate changes in circulating arachidonic acid levels in patients with FluA, RSV, or COVID-19 and assess its potential as a diagnostic or prognostic biomarker.
results_summary: The study found reduced arachidonic acid concentrations in patients with viral lung diseases compared to healthy individuals, with the most pronounced reductions in COVID-19 patients. However, IL-6 outperformed arachidonic acid as a diagnostic and prognostic biomarker.
population_specificity: 172 FluA, 80 RSV, and 217 COVID-19 patients, and 104 healthy volunteers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the metabolic regulation of allergic inflammation, focusing on the role of arachidonic acid-derived metabolites in immune dysfunction and epithelial barrier dysfunction in allergies.
results_summary: The study found that arachidonic acid-derived metabolites, such as cysteinyl leukotrienes and prostaglandins, are significant markers of immune and epithelial barrier dysfunction in allergic conditions like asthma, atopic dermatitis, and allergic rhinitis. Eosinophils, which utilize these metabolites, exhibit metabolic plasticity and directly promote allergic symptoms.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on allergic inflammation mechanisms)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety, tolerance, and growth outcomes of an infant formula containing Arachidonic Acid (ARA) in infants with feeding intolerance or suspected cow's milk allergy.
results_summary: The study found that the formula containing ARA was safe and well-tolerated, supporting significant weight gain in infants. No adverse effects specific to ARA were reported.
population_specificity: Infants 0-90 days old with persistent feeding intolerance, suspected cow's milk or soy allergy, or conditions requiring hydrolyzed formula.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mediators, genomic and epigenomic characteristics involved in arachidonic acid metabolism and clopidogrel activation could improve the prediction of aspirin and clopidogrel resistance in addition to cardiovascular risk factors.
results_summary: The study found that specific genotypes (e.g., TXAS1 A/A) and promoter methylations (e.g., ALOX12) improved the prediction of ischemic stroke recurrence and laboratory resistance (ARU and PRU levels) when integrated with cardiovascular risk factors. The models showed modest but significant improvements in sensitivity and predictive accuracy.
population_specificity: 988 patients with transient ischemic attack and ischemic stroke.
study_duration: 12 weeks after aspirin and clopidogrel administration

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize and update the biological functions of arachidonic acid pathways in cardiometabolic diseases and discuss their cellular and molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that arachidonic acid derivatives and pathway factors link metabolic disorders to cardiovascular risks and play a significant role in the progression and severity of cardiometabolic diseases, including heart failure, hypertension, and diabetes. It also highlighted emerging clinical advances targeting these pathways to improve pathological conditions.
population_specificity: General focus on cardiometabolic diseases (heart failure, hypertension, atherosclerosis, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, obesity, diabetes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the role of arachidonic acid in myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury (MIRI) and explore pharmacological interventions targeting its pathway.
results_summary: The study found that arachidonic acid, released by sPLA2, contributes to inflammation and reperfusion injury in MIRI by serving as a substrate for eicosanoid biosynthetic enzymes. It also highlighted the potential of targeting sPLA2 and mitochondrial cardiolipin modifications to mitigate MIRI.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on molecular and mechanistic analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of arachidonic acid-derived eicosanoids in Alzheimer's disease progression and their potential as therapeutic targets.
results_summary: The study found that eicosanoids, derived from arachidonic acid, have a dual role in Alzheimer's disease, either promoting or inhibiting its progression depending on their influence on brain immune responses. The precise mechanisms remain unclear, but targeting eicosanoid signaling shows therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on Alzheimer's disease pathology)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether supplementation with arachidonic acid could help prevent retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) in preterm infants.
results_summary: The study suggests that arachidonic acid supplementation, alongside other interventions, may help prevent ROP and reduce the need for treatment, though specific efficacy data are not detailed.
population_specificity: Preterm and extremely preterm infants at risk of ROP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of high-intensity statin therapy on plasma bioactive lipids, including arachidonic acid, to understand its role in inflammation and cardioprotective properties.
results_summary: Statin therapy significantly lowered arachidonic acid levels, which are associated with proinflammatory and proplatelet aggregation activity, suggesting a potential reduction in inflammatory pathways.
population_specificity: Individuals with low-density lipoprotein cholesterol <130 mg/dL and high-sensitivity C-reactive protein ≥2 mg/L in a primary prevention trial.
effective_dosage: Not specified for arachidonic acid (statin dosage not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to scrutinize the role of arachidonic acid metabolism in aging and explore its potential as a therapeutic target for aging-related diseases.
results_summary: The study highlights the essential role of arachidonic acid metabolism in aging tissues and organs, linking it to conditions like osteoporosis and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and suggests potential anti-aging therapies targeting this pathway.
population_specificity: Aging world population (general focus, not specific demographic).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of aspirin dose on platelet inhibition in children with congenital and acquired heart disease, with a focus on the parameter MAAA (maximum amplitude with arachidonic acid).
results_summary: The study found that younger children (<2 years) required higher aspirin doses (5 mg/kg/day) for effective platelet inhibition, while older children (>2 years) showed responsiveness at lower doses (3 mg/kg/day). Laboratory assessment was recommended to avoid under- or overdosing.
population_specificity: Children (<2 years and >2 years) with congenital and acquired cardiac disease.
effective_dosage: Median dose of 4.72 (4.18-6.05) mg/kg/day for higher-dose quartile (Q4); 3 mg/kg/day for older children.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the association between excess fat consumption, particularly long-chain n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (LC n-3 PUFA), and the risk of colorectal cancer (CRC).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding Arachidonic Acid's effects, focusing instead on LC n-3 PUFA like EPA and DHA.
population_specificity: Not specified in the provided abstract.

study_goal: The abstract does not specify the study's goal regarding Arachidonic Acid.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Arachidonic Acid.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the potential role of omega-6 fatty acids, including Arachidonic Acid, in the increasing incidence and progression of colorectal cancer.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Arachidonic Acid's effects, only mentioning its association with Westernized diets and colorectal cancer risk.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of autophagy and mitochondrial regulation in mast cell activation, including the involvement of arachidonic acid metabolites in allergic and inflammatory responses.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that mast cell activation leads to the production of arachidonic acid metabolites, but it does not provide specific findings on arachidonic acid's effects. The focus is on autophagy and mitochondrial regulation as potential therapeutic targets for allergic diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the functional roles of CYP4 genes, particularly their involvement in the metabolism of arachidonic acid and its impact on metabolic dysfunction-associated fatty liver disease (MASLD).
